awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Light-Weight and Fast Authentication for Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
Internet of Things (IoT) is a heterogeneous system comprising interrelated smart-objects, sensors and actuators. IoT systems are expected to ultimately usher significant advances in critical domains such as transportation, energy, and healthcare. Due to IoTs' pervasiveness and impact on the cyber-physical world, it is a vital requirement to guarantee their security. In particular, authentication is one of the most fundamental security services required for any viable IoT, since it is necessary to establish trust and secure the communication among parties in a network. However, despite their merits, the vast majority of existing authentication techniques may not fully meet the needs of IoTs, especially when such systems involve heterogeneous IoTs with resource-limited devices or, must meet real-time requirements for safety reasons (e.g., delay-sensitive networks). Hence, there is a critical need for developing authentication techniques, which are lightweight, fast and scalable for heterogeneous and delay-sensitive IoTs. The objective of this project is to establish an integrated program of research and education to develop practical cryptographic techniques towards the creation of secure IoTs, as well as to develop academic course materials and outreach activities for the education and broad dissemination of the proposed techniques. The successful completion of this project is expected to provide new opportunities to significantly enhance the trustworthiness of IoTs by enabling practical authentication techniques, thereby greatly contributing towards a broad adaptation of IoT.

The research activities in this project will be focused on the creation of a suite of lightweight and low-latency digital signatures. Expected outcomes include: (1) A new suite of highly lightweight digital signatures for resource-limited and heterogeneous IoTs. (2)  A new series of high-performance, compromise-resilient and compact digital signatures. (3) A new suite of low-latency digital signatures for delay-sensitive IoTs. (4) A comprehensive formal security analysis, optimization and hardware-acceleration of the proposed techniques. (5) A new IoT testbed that will be used for the evaluation, improvement and education of the proposed techniques. (6) An industrial secure IoT research platform and open-source cryptographic framework, in which the proposed techniques will be deployed and improved on real-life IoT systems in collaboration with research laboratories. The educational objective is to design, implement and evaluate educational modules and outreach activities to educate students at various levels (i.e., high-school, undergraduate and graduate) in the field of cyber-security for IoT. This will be achieved via newly introduced course modules that focus on hands-on experience of the proposed techniques on real-life IoT platforms, and with various cyber-security outreach activities designed to target middle-school and female high-school and undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
The Internet of Things (IoT) harbors several interconnected smart objects and plays a vital role in critical domains like artificial intelligence, healthcare, transportation, and national security. Due to their significant impact on real-life applications, it is crucial to protect IoTs from cyberattacks. This project aimed to create an integrated research and education program to develop practical cybersecurity and cryptographic techniques for IoTs, thereby protecting the nation and its citizens from cyber harm targeting IoT systems.

 This research has resulted in a substantial number of significant research results demonstrated through flagship publications (35 publications including top venues such as CCS, NDSS, PETs, Infocomm, IEEE/ACM Transactions like TIFS, TDSC, TSC, TOPs, etc…) and 10 patents with substantial real-life impact. All these research outcomes are supported with practical deployments and 15 open-source cybersecurity frameworks that are available for public use and potential adaptations. In addition to high-impact research outcomes, this CAREER award supported the development of a cybersecurity workforce and educational programs sorely needed by the nation via the creation of 5 cyber-security courses, several educational modules, and outreach research activities engaging over 150 young female students. Finally, this award supported 3 Ph.D. students, 3 MS students, and over 10 REUs, many of whom execute academic and cybersecurity positions that continue to benefit education and national security. Some selected examples of advancements made via this award are as follows:   

* Breakthrough Techniques for Lightweight Digital Signatures on Embedded IoTs (conventional and post-quantum): We created a series of highly lightweight digital signatures that can meet the stringent performance needs of resource-limited IoT devices. Specifically, we created efficient digital signatures that are one to two magnitudes more computationally efficient than their most efficient counterparts with small signature sizes. Notable advancements made on lightweight post-quantum digital signatures by addressing challenges of expensive operations in post-quantum cryptography. The high signer efficiency achieved via such innovations translates into longer battery life and enhanced sustainability by positively impacting myriad real-life applications. Some examples include but are not limited to extending the lifespan of medical/wearable devices in healthcare, smart-city applications, digital twins, and resilient military networks.

* Novel Delay-Aware Authentication Techniques for Real-time IoT Systems (conventional and post-quantum): We developed several fast digital signatures that respect the delay-sensitive nature of real-time IoT applications. Some critical cyber-physical systems (e.g., vehicular networks) need secure authentication yet are also highly sensitive to delays. For instance, the delay introduced due to authentication might impact brake time negatively, jeopardizing the safety of passengers in autonomous driving applications. We developed novel digital signatures offering one to two magnitudes lower end-to-end cryptographic delay with respect to their counterparts. High-speed digital signatures are difficult to attain in post-quantum settings, and we made various advancements on this front via fast lattice-based signatures. The high-speed cryptographic algorithms designed in this project enhance the security and reliability of several next-generation networked systems such as 6G, vehicular/drone networks, smart-grid systems, and satellite-terrestrial networks, thereby improving the national security and safety of the citizens. 

* Innovations on Privacy Enhancing Technologies (PETs) for Enhanced Trust, Usability, and Performance: We developed a vast range of new PETs that enhance the privacy of the users while permitting various functionalities. One of the prominent results was shown via the novel Dynamic Symmetric Searchable Encryption (DSSE) schemes that permit a database to be kept encrypted while still allowing users to query it. Our new DSSE schemes found worldwide deployment within Robert Bosch databases, positively impacting millions of users. Moreover, we introduced one of the first post-quantum public key-based searchable encryption methods. Another line of innovation made on oblivious access methods permits wireless mobile network users to protect their location and query privacy. The project also made a breakthrough in distributed cryptography by creating distributed oblivious access, secure multi-party computation methods, and proof of retrievability. Innovations made through PETs and trustworthy computing benefit citizens on a broad range of real-life applications such as trusted cloud computing, secure medical databases, secure machine learning, and green computing, are some to mention. 

* New Educational Programs and Enhanced Cybersecurity Workforce: This project supported PI, 3 Ph.D., 3 MS, and several undergraduate students working on the intersections of applied cryptography and network security. Two PhD students are now tenure-track professors at respected universities, while some others work in research laboratories. Courses developed with the support of this project play a key role in the cybersecurity curriculums at multiple universities. The outreach activities involving REUs and young minority students led to various job opportunities in the field of cyber-security.
